title: Converting Between Metric Units
description: Master conversions between kilometres, metres, centimetres, and millimetres, as well as other metric units.
objectives: Convert between metric units of length, mass, and capacity
Understand the relationship between kilometres, metres, centimetres, and millimetres

sections.title: The Metric System Makes Sense!
sections.content: The metric system is beautifully organised — everything is based on **powers of $10$**. This makes converting between units much easier than you might think. Whether you're working with length, mass, or capacity, the same principles apply.

sections.title: Metric Length Conversions
sections.content:
Here are the key relationships for length:

$$1 \text{ km} = 1{,}000 \text{ m}$$
$$1 \text{ m} = 100 \text{ cm}$$
$$1 \text{ cm} = 10 \text{ mm}$$
$$1 \text{ m} = 1{,}000 \text{ mm}$$

**To convert from a larger unit to a smaller unit:** multiply (more small units needed).

**To convert from a smaller unit to a larger unit:** divide (fewer large units needed).

For example: $3.5 \text{ km} = 3.5 \times 1{,}000 = 3{,}500 \text{ m}$.

sections.title: Mass and Capacity Conversions
sections.content:
**Mass:**
$$1 \text{ t (tonne)} = 1{,}000 \text{ kg}$$
$$1 \text{ kg} = 1{,}000 \text{ g}$$

**Capacity:**
$$1 \text{ L} = 1{,}000 \text{ mL}$$

The pattern is always the same: each step up is $\times 1{,}000$ (or $\times 100$ for cm/m, or $\times 10$ for mm/cm).

sections.title: Example: Multi-Step Conversion
steps: First convert km to m: $2.75 \times 1{,}000 = 2{,}750 \text{ m}$.
Then convert m to cm: $2{,}750 \times 100 = 275{,}000 \text{ cm}$.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- The metric system is based on **powers of $10$**, making conversions straightforward.
- **Multiply** when going from larger to smaller units; **divide** when going from smaller to larger.
- Key facts: $1 \text{ km} = 1{,}000 \text{ m}$, $1 \text{ m} = 100 \text{ cm}$, $1 \text{ cm} = 10 \text{ mm}$, $1 \text{ kg} = 1{,}000 \text{ g}$, $1 \text{ L} = 1{,}000 \text{ mL}$.

workedExamples.title: Converting with Decimals
steps: To convert cm to m, divide by $100$.
workedExamples.explanation: Dividing by $100$ moves the decimal point two places to the left.

workedExamples.title: Real-World Conversion Problem
workedExamples.problem: A runner completes a $5 \text{ km}$ race. How many metres did they run?
workedExamples.explanation: Multiply by $1{,}000$ to convert kilometres to metres.

title: Area of Rectangles and Triangles, and Volume
description: Calculate areas of rectangles and triangles, and find the volume of rectangular prisms.
objectives: Calculate the area of rectangles using length times width
Calculate the area of triangles using half base times height
Calculate the volume of rectangular prisms

sections.title: From Flat to 3D!
sections.content: You've already learned to find the area of rectangles. Now we're going to tackle **triangles** too, and take the leap into the third dimension with **volume**. Volume tells us how much space a 3D shape takes up — like how much water a fish tank can hold.

sections.title: Area of Rectangles (Revision)
sections.content:
The area of a rectangle is:

$$\text{Area} = \text{length} \times \text{width}$$

For a rectangle with length $8 \text{ cm}$ and width $5 \text{ cm}$:
$$\text{Area} = 8 \times 5 = 40 \text{ cm}^2$$

Remember: area is always measured in **square units** ($\text{cm}^2$, $\text{m}^2$, etc.).

sections.title: Area of Triangles
sections.content:
A triangle is exactly **half** of a rectangle (imagine cutting a rectangle diagonally). So:

$$\text{Area of a triangle} = \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$$

Or equivalently: $\text{Area} = \frac{\text{base} \times \text{height}}{2}$

The **base** is any side of the triangle. The **height** is the perpendicular distance from the base to the opposite vertex (the top point).

sections.title: Volume of Rectangular Prisms
sections.content:
**Volume** measures the space inside a 3D shape. For a rectangular prism (like a box):

$$\text{Volume} = \text{length} \times \text{width} \times \text{height}$$

Volume is measured in **cubic units** ($\text{cm}^3$, $\text{m}^3$, etc.).

For a box that is $6 \text{ cm}$ long, $4 \text{ cm}$ wide, and $3 \text{ cm}$ high:
$$\text{Volume} = 6 \times 4 \times 3 = 72 \text{ cm}^3$$

This means you could fit $72$ cubes (each $1 \text{ cm} \times 1 \text{ cm} \times 1 \text{ cm}$) inside the box.

sections.title: Example: Area of a Triangle
sections.content: A triangle has a base of $10 \text{ cm}$ and a height of $6 \text{ cm}$. Find its area.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- **Area of a rectangle** $= \text{length} \times \text{width}$ (in $\text{cm}^2$ or $\text{m}^2$).
- **Area of a triangle** $= \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$.
- **Volume of a rectangular prism** $= \text{length} \times \text{width} \times \text{height}$ (in $\text{cm}^3$ or $\text{m}^3$).
- A triangle is half a rectangle, which is why we divide by $2$.

workedExamples.title: Volume of a Rectangular Prism
workedExamples.problem: A fish tank is $50 \text{ cm}$ long, $30 \text{ cm}$ wide, and $40 \text{ cm}$ high. What is its volume?
workedExamples.explanation: The volume tells us how much water the tank can hold. Since $1{,}000 \text{ cm}^3 = 1 \text{ L}$, this tank holds $60$ litres.

workedExamples.title: Comparing Areas
workedExamples.problem: Which has a greater area: a rectangle $12 \text{ cm} \times 5 \text{ cm}$ or a triangle with base $12 \text{ cm}$ and height $10 \text{ cm}$?
steps: They have the **same area**: $60 \text{ cm}^2$ each!
workedExamples.answer: They have equal areas of $60 \text{ cm}^2$.
workedExamples.explanation: Different shapes can have the same area. The triangle needs a greater height to compensate for only using half the base-times-height product.

title: Time: 12/24 Hour Clock and Timetables
description: Convert between 12-hour and 24-hour time, and read timetables to plan journeys.

sections.title: What Time Is It... Really?
sections.content: Your phone might show $14\text{:}30$ while a clock on the wall says $2\text{:}30$ pm. They mean the same time! The **24-hour clock** is used for timetables, the military, and digital devices. Let's learn to switch between the two systems and read timetables like a pro.

sections.title: Reading Timetables
sections.content:
Timetables show departure and arrival times for transport. To find journey time, subtract the departure time from the arrival time.

| Station | Train 1 | Train 2 | Train 3 |
|---|---|---|---|
| Melbourne | $08\text{:}15$ | $09\text{:}30$ | $11\text{:}00$ |
| Geelong | $09\text{:}20$ | $10\text{:}35$ | $12\text{:}05$ |
| Warrnambool | $11\text{:}45$ | $13\text{:}00$ | $14\text{:}30$ |

For Train 1, Melbourne to Geelong: $09\text{:}20 - 08\text{:}15 = 1$ hour $5$ minutes.

sections.title: Example: Using a Timetable
sections.content: Using the timetable above, which train should you catch from Melbourne if you need to arrive in Warrnambool before $1\text{:}00$ pm?
steps: Train 1 arrives in Warrnambool at $11\text{:}45$ — before $13\text{:}00$. This works!
Train 2 arrives at $13\text{:}00$ — this is exactly $1\text{:}00$ pm, not before it.
You need to catch **Train 1** (departing Melbourne at $08\text{:}15$).

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- **24-hour time** runs from $00\text{:}00$ (midnight) to $23\text{:}59$.
- **Add $12$** to convert pm hours to 24-hour time. **Subtract $12$** to convert back.
- **Timetables** show scheduled departure and arrival times.
- Calculate **journey time** by subtracting departure from arrival.

workedExamples.title: Converting Time Formats
workedExamples.problem: Convert $4\text{:}20$ pm to 24-hour time, and convert $16\text{:}50$ to 12-hour time.
steps: $4\text{:}20$ pm: add $12$ to the hours: $4 + 12 = 16$. Answer: $16\text{:}20$.
$16\text{:}50$: subtract $12$ from the hours: $16 - 12 = 4$. Answer: $4\text{:}50$ pm.
workedExamples.explanation: For afternoon and evening times (pm), add $12$ to get 24-hour format. For 24-hour times $13\text{:}00$ and above, subtract $12$ and add 'pm'.

workedExamples.title: Calculating Journey Time
workedExamples.problem: A bus departs at $09\text{:}45$ and arrives at $11\text{:}20$. How long is the journey?
workedExamples.explanation: Breaking the journey into parts (to the next hour, then complete hours, then remaining minutes) makes the calculation straightforward.
